history.content:
In terms of workload, there is a slight imbalance, in that your spring semester seems much more challenging/time-consuming than your fall semester. I would suggest swapping CS 170 for CS 168 in order to balance it out. Moreover, CS 170 is one of the most important CS upperdivs and the sooner you take it, the better prepared you will be for technical interviews and industry.

-----

I agree with the above user, in that the Spring semester seems to be significantly more work - both 186 and 161 have ramped up in terms of workload recently, and 170 is a heavy class.

What could help is swapping around 161 and 188; 161 doesn't really need much of 61C, since they go over all the memory stuff you need for 161 again in the first few weeks of the class, and that swap would probably improve your schedule. 

Also consider swapping 170 for 61C - as the above student mentioned, 170 is pretty useful for interviews and the like, so it might help to take that first (so your schedule would look like 170/161/168 (Fall) and 61C/186/188 (Spring), which does seem pretty balanced and fair)

In terms of workload, there is a slight imbalance, in that your spring semester seems much more challenging/time-consuming than your fall semester. I would suggest swapping CS 170 for CS 168 in order to balance it out. Moreover, CS 170 is one of the most important CS upperdivs and the sooner you take it, the better prepared you will be for technical interviews and industry.

children.subject: The only issue with that is that 168 is only offered in the Fall iirc. So I wouldn't be able to swap it for a class in the Spring.

history.content:
Fall: 61C / 188 / 168

Spring: 170 / 186 / 161

How are these schedules in terms of workloads?
history.subject: Planning my final year
